bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 164, Number 158 (Tuesday, September 25, 2018)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Ms. VELAZQUEZ:H.R. 6869.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8, Clause 1The Congress shall have Power to . . . provide for the . .. general Welfare of the United States; . . .[Page H8885]

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs.
Referred to the Subcommittee on Health.

item.fullName: Del. Radewagen, Aumua Amata Coleman [R-AS-At Large]
Del. Sablan, Gregorio Kilili Camacho [D-MP-At Large]

item.name: Emergency medical services and trauma care

item.text:
Violence Against Women Veterans Act

This bill requires the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to carry out a program to assist veterans who have experienced domestic violence or sexual assault access VA benefits.

The VA shall establish a national task force to address domestic violence and sexual assault among veterans and conduct a study to determine the scope of the problem.
item.name: Introduced in House

bill.title: Violence Against Women Veterans Act

item.title: To require the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to improve the provision of services and benefits from the Department of Veterans Affairs for veterans who experience domestic violence or sexual assault, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
